questions.text: A 9-year-old boy complains of sharp shooting pain in right pelvic region for 2 days associated with vomiting. The pain is not relieved with common analgesics. It is waxing and waning since last 3 months. There is a family history of renal stones in father and grandfather. Which of the following investigation should be first line in acute condition?
questions.solution:
• Differentials to be considered in this case is Renal stone, appendicitis, bowel obstruction and Ureteropelvic junction obstruction.
  • However, with a strong family history of renal stones with recurrent colicky pain, diagnosis goes more in favor of renal stones.
  • In all the above conditions first line of investigation is Abdominal ultrasound.

Option C: If diagnosis still uncertain, consider low-dose non-contrast CT scan of kidneys, ureters and bladder.

Option B: The CT is more likely to pick up stones smaller than 3mm, but due to radiation, USG remains the first line.

Option D: MRI is used for soft tissue lesions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The first line of investigation for Renal stones is Abdominal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl has high-grade fever and burning urination. She has been diagnosed with E.coli positive urinary tract infection. The parents asks about the likelihood of the infection to reoccur. Which of the following is not a risk factor for recurrent UTI?
questions.solution:
Recurrent UTI is defined as:

  • Two or more episodes of upper UTI (pyelonephritis)
  • One episode of upper UTI and one episode of lower UTI
  • Three episodes of lower UTI

Risk factor for recurrent UTI are:

  • Younger children - aged less than 6 months
  • Girls compared to boys
  • VUR grade 3-5
  • Voiding abnormalities

Reference: Treatment guidelines for UTI in children, 2022, IAP

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classic feature of a salt-losing crisis in an infant with congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
• In CAH, an enzyme deficiency in the steroid hormone synthesis pathway can lead to a combined cortisol and aldosterone insufficiency.
  • Aldosterone promotes water and sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium by upregulating Na/K pump activity in the distal nephron. Its absence therefore results in a salt-losing crisis with hyponatraemia, hyperkalaemia (and associated metabolic acidosis), and hypotension. At the same time, the lack of cortisol causes

questions.text: What is the normal value of creatinine on first day of life in a full term baby?
questions.solution: • Normal serum creatinine values at day 1 are 0.8-1.0 mg/dL, 7-0.8 mg/dL at day 3 and <0.6mg/dL by 7 days of life.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome, first episode. Which of the following feature is considered as atypical and confers nephrologist opinion and later renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
• The following atypical features would prompt discussion with a nephrologist and consideration of renal biopsy:
    • Age < 1 year or > 12 years (Option A)
    • Hypertension
    • Impaired renal function
    • Frank haematuria
    • Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome
  • Option C and D: Periorbital edema and heavy proteinuria are typical features of Nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 4 month old girl has E.coli positive UTI. She has responded well to antibiotics and is afebrile after 48 hours. Which of the following imaging modality is to be done in the child?

questions.text: A young child has recently moved house and has been complaining of abdominal pain, which parents have put down to the child been upset about the move. He is now developed with seizures and renal failure. You suspect a poisoning. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Lead poisoning is more common in younger children due to the tendency for pica. In a child that has recently moved to an older home which may have lead paint this should be considered.
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms of lead poisoning include anorexia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation, often occurring and recurring over a period of weeks.
  • Central nervous system symptoms are related to worsening cerebral edema and increased intracranial pressure. Headaches, change in mentation, lethargy, papilledema, seizures, and coma
  • At high levels (>100 μg/dL), renal tubular dysfunction is observed.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is having first episode of nephrotic syndrome and is started on oral steroids. He develops severe abdominal pain. Which of the following complications must be considered on priority in this child and investigated?
questions.solution:
• Nephrotic children are in a pro-thrombotic state and if thrombosis occurs in this group it carries a significant morbidity and mortality.
  • Be particularly wary of nephrotic children who complain of chest or abdominal pain as they could be presenting with pulmonary embolism or mesenteric ischemia.

Option a, c and d are not considered on priority in this child and investigated.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Antithrombin III: This important protein that helps to regulate blood clotting is lost in significant amounts through the urine due to glomerular damage. Low levels increase the risk of clot formation.

Protein C and Protein S: Both are critical for the regulation of clotting. Their levels may also be decreased, further promoting a prothrombotic environment.

questions.text: Most common organism causing Urinary tract infection in Indian children is?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of UTIs in Indian children are Coli(about 85% or more), Klebsiella species and Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

Option B: Klebsiella: especially in children with underlying health issues or hospital-acquired infections.

Option C: Staphylococcus: Although more common in young females, it can occasionally cause UTIs in children.

Option D: Candida species: Fungal UTIs can occur, especially in immunocompromised children or those with prolonged antibiotic use.

Reference: Standard treatment guidelines for urinary tract infections, IAP, 2022, pg. 5

choices.text: Observe and treat only if symptomatic

questions.text: A child with nephrotic syndrome on high dose steroids comes in contact with an active case of chicken pox in neighborhood. He is not vaccinated to varicella. Which of the following treatment is advised for this child?
questions.solution:
• Following close contact with varicella infection, give immunocompromised children on immunosuppressive agents varicella-zoster immune globulin if available; immunize healthy household contacts with live vaccines to minimize the risk of transfer of infection to the immunosuppressed child, but avoid direct exposure of the child to gastrointestinal or respiratory secretions of vaccinated contacts for 3-6 weeks after vaccination.
  • Live vaccines are contraindicated for this child. (Option A)
  • IV acyclovir is recommended by some literature. (Option C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Live vaccines are contraindicated in patients with nephrotic syndrome.

choices.text: Symptomatic treatment to prevent dehydration and electrolyte disturbances
A single IM dose of ceftriaxone

questions.text: A previously well 5-year-old boy presents with recent onset of abdominal pain and diarrhea (that has contained blood on several occasions). A stool culture is subsequently positive for Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli O157:H7. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Most children with diarrhea caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli O157:H7 (STEC) should be treated only with fluid replacement and not an antimicrobial agent.
  • Patients treated with an antimicrobial for STEC hemorrhagic colitis are at greater risk of developing hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) as its use can increase the toxin production.

Option D: TMP/SMX is drug of choice for EIEC, ETEC and EPEC.

Option A and C are not commonly used in these infections.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Most children with diarrhea caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli O157:H7 (STEC) should be treated only with fluid replacement and not an antimicrobial agent.

questions.text: A 10-month-old female infant is seen for follow up 2 weeks after diagnosed with Escherichia coli urinary tract infection. Ultrasonography had shown left-sided moderate hydronephrosis without ureteral dilatation and a normal right kidney. She completed a 10-day course of cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram performed after discharge had normal findings. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of hydronephrosis in this infant is
questions.solution:
The common differential diagnoses of unilateral hydronephrosis are:

  • Ureteropelvic junction obstruction
  • Uretero-vesical junction obstruction
  • Ureterocele
  • Ectopic ureter
  • Unilateral vesicoureteral reflux
  • Transient physiologic cause.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hydronephrosis without ureteral dilation favours a proximal obstruction (ureteropelvic junction) rather than distal obstruction (ureterovesical junction), ureterocele, or ectopic ureter.

questions.text: A healthy 6-month-old boy is found incidentally to have a duplicated collecting system with no dilation. He has been asymptomatic and has been growing well. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• About 25% of anomalies recognized prenatally are congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract. These disorders are varied and may be caused by malformations in the renal parenchyma, disruption in renal migration, or abnormalities in the developing collecting system.
  • Duplication of the collecting system is the most frequently seen congenital urinary tract anomaly and may occur as either complete duplication or partial duplication, which is more common.
  • Duplication is likely the result of ureteric bud duplication. Two distinct pelvicalyceal systems and either one ureter or two ureters that converge proximal to the bladder are present in children with partial duplication.
  • Children with complete duplication also have two distinct pelvicaliceal systems but with two ureters. One ureter typically inserts in the trigone area of the bladder, while the second may insert there or elsewhere in the genitourinary system. In girls, it may enter at the bladder neck, urethrovaginal septum, vagina, cervix, uterus, Gartner duct, or a urethral diverticulum. In boys, it may insert into the posterior urethra, prostatic utricle, seminal vesicle, ejaculatory duct, or vas deferens.
  • For patients, like this boy, who are asymptomatic and do not have dilatation or urinary tract infection, treatment is not indicated and the patient may be observed.

questions.text: A newborn infant has severe respiratory distress and is noted to have pseudoepicanthus, flattened ears and nose, and bilateral club feet. There is no family history of renal failure. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals bilaterally enlarged echogenic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation; there are no cysts or hydronephrosis. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate's condition is
questions.solution:
• Potter syndrome/Potter sequence/oligohydramnios sequence is the characteristic phenotypic features in the neonate caused by oligohydramnios.
  • The characteristic features include pulmonary hypoplasia (respiratory distress in the newborn), abnormal facial appearance (pseudoepicanthus, flattened ears and nose, recessed chin), and limb abnormalities (club feet and hip dislocation).
  • Potter syndrome type 1 occurs in association with ARPKD.
  • On ultrasonography, patients with ARPKD have enlarged echogenic kidneys without obvious renal cysts whereas ADPKD is associated with macrocysts. (Option A)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Potter syndrome/Potter sequence/oligohydramnios sequence is the characteristic phenotypic features in the neonate caused by oligohydramnios

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with the history of having cola-colored urine for one day. He had mild sore throat without fever 4 weeks ago. On examination, the boy has normal growth parameters. He has a RR of 18 breaths/min, HR of 94 beats/min, and BP of 138/90 mm Hg. The remainder of the physical examination findings is normal. A urine test strip analysis demonstrates a specific gravity of 1.015, pH of 5.5, 3+ blood, 2+ leukocyte esterase, and no protein or nitrites. Of the following, the test MOST likely to offer both diagnostic and prognostic information about this boy's condition is
questions.solution:
• Acute glomerulonephritis is characterized by the triad of cola-colored urine, hypertension, and azotemia on serum chemistry. These patients may or may not have proteinuria with or without hypoalbuminemia.
  • Serum complement evaluation is important for characterizing patients with acute nephritis. Patients with nephritis may have hypocomplementemic (associated with a low C3) or normocomplementemic (associated with a normal C3) glomerulonephritis.
  • Hypocomplementemia usually resolves within 8 weeks in postinfectious GN (PIGN). Persistently low C3 level is associated with an increased risk for membranoproliferative GN and possibly a poorer prognosis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old adolescent presents for follow-up 3 months after a diagnosis of acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Laboratory testing at this visit reveals microscopic hematuria and a persistently low C3. Based on these findings, what diagnosis should you consider at this time?
questions.solution:
• This patient was diagnosed with acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) likely based on clinical presentation, because biopsy is no longer routine for diagnosis. However, at this visit, his C3 remains low. In APSGN, it is expected that the C3 levels will normalize in 2 to 3 months. Because this patient continues to have depressed C3, he was likely misdiagnosed initially. Persistent hypocomplementemia is suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Option C: Recurrent painless gross hematuria, frequently associated with an upper respiratory tract infection, is typical of IgA nephropathy. These patients often develop chronic renal disease over decades.

Option B: The classic triad associated with IgA vasculitis (HSP) is purpuric rash, arthritis, and abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 7-month-old girl presents to your clinic with recurrent episodes of fever, vomiting and chronic constipation associated with poor weight gain. Urinalysis shows a pH of 5.0, specific gravity of 1.010, 1+ protein and 1+ glucose with a normal urine anion gap. Blood work shows a decreased phosphorus and calcium, elevated serum chloride, and a normal glucose and albumin level. Arterial blood gas shows a metabolic acidosis. What would best explain these findings?
questions.solution:
• This child has symptoms and laboratory studies consistent with Fanconi syndrome, otherwise known as global proximal tubular dysfunction.
  • It can be hereditary or acquired. Inherited forms are secondary to a genetic abnormality, such as galactosemia, Wilson disease and cystinosis.
  • Acquired forms are usually secondary to drugs and substances (e.g., gentamicin, valproic acid, cisplatin, 6-mercaptopurines, lead, mercury, uranium, platinum, and toluene) through acute tubular necrosis, alteration of renal blood flow, intratubular obstruction and allergic reactions.
  • It is a generalized defect in the proximal tubule leading to:
    • Polyuria: Increased urination.
    • Polydipsia: Increased thirst due to loss of water.
    • Glycosuria: Presence of glucose in the urine despite normal blood glucose levels.
    • Aminoaciduria: Excess amino acids in the urine.
    • Phosphaturia: Increased phosphate excretion, which can lead to bone issues.
    • Metabolic Acidosis: Due to bicarbonate loss.
  • Hence, the syndrome is characterized by low molecular weight proteinuria, glycosuria, phosphaturia, aminoaciduria and proximal renal tubular acidosis.
  • Patients may present with growth failure early in the first year of life, with symptoms secondary to phosphate wasting, such as rickets.
  • Specific laboratory abnormalities include glucosuria, normal blood sugar, high urine pH, mild to moderate serum hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, mild albuminuria, and normal serum protein and albumin.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Fanconi syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by a dysfunction in the renal tubules of the kidneys, leading to a variety of metabolic abnormalities. It primarily affects the proximal renal tubules, resulting in the impaired reabsorption of substances that should normally be reabsorbed from the urine back into the bloodstream.
